sentence: M arquee names in the retail industry gave ETF investors something to be thankful for this week.Lowe's ( LOW ) hammered out financial growth.Home Depot ( HD ) andWal-Mart ( WMT ) came off looking good too, ahead of Black Friday.
The consumer discretionary sector is leading Q3 earnings growth, which is expected to continue in 2016, says a recent S&P Capital IQ report.
The retail industry is driving the sector's performance.
But not all retailers are performing equally well, the report added.
Department stores and apparel retailers suchMacy's ( M ),Nordstrom ( JWN ) andGap (GPS) have been a weak spot this reporting season.
That dispersion may impact investors' choice of ETF strategy .
"It's extremely important for investors to look at what exposure they are getting instead of assuming all things are equal," says Todd Rosenbluth, S&P Capital IQ's director of ETF research.
Consumer Discretionary Select Sector SPDR (XLY), the bellwether exchange traded fund in its category, offers exposure to retailers.
But its heaviest stake is in media stocks such asComcast (CMCSA).
XLY has jumped 12% year to date through Wednesday, topping every other peer, thanks in part to outperformance by online behemothAmazon.com (AMZN), its top holding and an IBD Leaderboard stock.
"The Internet and catalog retail group is by far showing the strongest growth," said Rosenbluth.
Specialty retailers such as home improvement stores and automotives also offer strong growth potential, according to Capital IQ.
XLY allocates 16% of assets to Internet and catalog retail, and 20% to specialty retail.
By comparison,Market Vectors Retail (RTH) offers 20% portfolio weighting to Internet and catalog retail (Amazon is also its No.
1 stock) and 28% to specialty retail.
But RTH isn't a pure-play consumer discretionary ETF, Rosenbluth notes.
It includes retailers in the consumer staples and health care sectors such asKroger (KR),Walgreens (WBA) andCVS (CVS).
Although RTH strays outside sector bounds, Rosenbluth likes the outlook for stocks such as CVS.
"Investors have favored the more defensive characteristics of these stocks" in an uncertain and choppy stock market , he said.
MeanwhileSPDR S&P Retail (XRT) assigns nearly 16% of its assets to Internet and catalog retail, and 17% to specialty retail.
But it has given up 8% year to date vs. a 7% gain for RTH.
XRT tracks an equal-weighted index.
So Amazon gets the same weighting as small-cap digital print companyShutterfly (SFLY) -- roughly 1%.
XRT's smaller-cap skew hasn't worked in its favor recently.
"We like the larger-cap companies better," Rosenbluth said.
He suggests that investors could "layer" consumer discretionary ETFs to their S&P 500 funds for added exposure to boost investment success in 2016.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
